_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The CJ Bio America Facility located in Fort Dodge, Iowa is subject to Program 3 RMP elements resulting from the storage of Anhydrous Ammonia. The summary below outlines the facility's procedure with regard to each element of the risk management program. A complete PSM/RMP Program SOP document is kept on file at the facility.



Compliance Audits:

1. CJ Bio America will audit processes covered under PSM and/or RMP, at minimum, every 3 years.

 a. Compliance audits will include certification that they have been evaluated by at least oneperson knowledgeable of the process

 b. Compliance audit findings will be reported to applicable management in a timely fashion after the audit's completion

 c. Responses to compliance audit findings will be determined promptly, documented, and deficiencies corrected as necessary

 d. The two most recent compliance audit reports and response reports will be retained

2. This element of PSM/RMP is addressed in the internal document EHS-SOP-015, EH&S Internal Audits.



Contractors:

1. CJ Bio America will:

 a. Evaluate potential contractors' safety performance and programs

 b. Inform contractors of potential fire, explosion, and toxic release hazards related to the contractor's work

 c. Provide applicable provisions of the facility's EAP to the contractor

 d. Implement safe work practices in order to control entrance, presence, and exit of contractors in covered process areas

 e. Periodically evaluate the performance of contractors, maintain a contract employee injury and illness log related to contractors' work in process areas

2. CJ Bio America will ensure contractors:

 a. Have their employees trained in the necessary safe work practices

 b. Have their employees instructed on the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards associated with their work

 c. Have shared with their employees the applicable provisions of the Emergency Action Plan

 d. Document employee l.D., date of training, and means to verify trai

ning was understood

 e. Assure their employees follow the safety rules of the facility

 f. Communicate to CJ Bio America of unique hazards posed by the contract work or hazards found by contractor's work

3. This element of PSM/RMP is addressed in the internal document EHS-SOP-021, Contractor Qualification.



Document Management System: 

1. CJ Bio America will identify a qualified person with the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the facility's RMP program.

2. Personnel in the position of Environmental Coordinator will be assigned responsibility for the aforementioned tasks.



Employee Participation:

1. CJ Bio America shall consult with employees on conduct and development of PHA and other elements of PSM. CJ Bio America shall provide employees access to PHA and all other information required under PSM & RMP standards.

2. CJ Bio America addresses employee participation through:

 a. Involving employees to make up the PHA team

 b. Interviewing employees of covered processes during PHA

 c. Interviewing employees during monthly safety patrols for general concerns about their processes

 d. Providing a forum for questions and concerns during monthly safety meeting wherein refresher training is given on rotating topics including PSM & RMP, anhydrous ammonia,and environmental responsibilities



Emergency Planning and Response:

1. CJ Bio America has developed an emergency response plan which addresses, at a minimum:

 a. Procedures for informing the public and emergency response personnel about accidental releases

 b. Emergency response plan shall be coordinated with the community emergency response plan and verified with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and Fire Department.

 c. Documentation of:

  i. Proper first aid and medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures

  ii. Procedures and measures for emergency response after a release of a regulated substance

  iii. Procedures for use, in

spection, and maintenance of emergency response equipment

 d. Training for all employees on relevant procedures and procedures to review and update the emergency response plan

2. This element of PSM/RMP is addressed in the facility's Emergency Action Plan, internal document EHS-PLAN-001.



Five Year Accident History:

1. CJ Bio America will include in the PSM & RMP manual records of accidents related to covered chemical(s) for a time period of no less than five years including the following data:

 a. Date, time, and duration of release

 b. Chemical(s) released

 c. Estimated quantity released in pounds

 d. NAICS code related to the process

 e. The type of release event and its source

 f. Weather conditions

 g. On-site impacts

 h. Offsite impacts

 i. Initiating event and contributing factors

 j. Whether offsite responders were notified

 k. Operational or process changes that resulted from investigation of the release

2. To date, CJ Bio America has had no accidents involving a covered chemical. EH&S personnel will retain accident history data for inclusion when this becomes applicable.



Hot Work Permit:

1. CJ Bio America requires hot work permitting for hot work performed on or near a covered process.

2. The permit must document fire prevention and protection requirements, identified in 29 CFR 1910.252(a), have been implemented prior to beginning the hot work operations. The permit shall indicate:

 a. The date authorized for hot work

 b. Identify the object on which the hot work is to be performed

 c. Document the fire prevention and protection measures implemented prior to hot work

 d. Kept on file until completion of the hot work operations

3. This element of PSM/RMP is addressed in the internal document EHS-SOP-006, Hot Work.



Incident Investigation: 

1. CJ Bio America will initiate an incident investigation as promptly as possible, but not later than 48 hours, following an incident.

 a. The investigation team shall include at least one p

erson knowledgeable in the process

 b. Incident investigations shall be promptly resolved

 c. Incident investigation findings and resolutions shall be documented

2. The incident investigation report will contain, at a minimum, the following information:

 a. Date of the incident

 b. Date investigation began

 c. Description of the incident

 d. Factors contributing to the incident

 e. Any recommendations resulting from the investigation

3. Incident investigation findings will be reviewed with affected personnel, including applicable contractors.

4. Incident investigation reports shall be retained for a minimum of 5 years.

5. This element of PSM/RMP is addressed in the internal document EHS-SOP-O2O, EH&S Incident Investigations.



Management of Change:

1. CJ Bio America will establish and implement written procedures to manage changes, with the exception of "replacement in kind" to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, and facilities that affect a covered process.

2. Procedures shall assure that the following considerations are addressed prior to any change:

 a. Technical basis for proposed change

 b. Impact of change on safety and health

 c. Modifications to operating procedures

 d. Necessary time period for the change

 e. Authorization requirements for the proposed change

3. If affected by a change, applicable PSI will be updated accordingly.

4. If affected by a change, applicable operating procedures will be updated accordingly.

5. Affected employees and contractors will be informed of and trained in the change prior to start up.

6. This element of PSM/RMP is addressed in the internal document QAC-SOP-718, Change Management.



Mechanical Integrity:

1. CJ Bio America will develop and implement written procedures to maintain the on-going integrity of process equipment. All employees taking part in maintaining covered process equipment must be trained on said procedures.

2. The facility shall perform inspections and tests on pro

cess equipment and assure that inspections and tests on process equipment follow recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices (GEP).

 a. The frequency of inspections and tests on process equipment must be consistent with manufacturer's recommendations and GEPs.

 b. Inspections and tests shall be documented including the date of the test, the person who performed it, equipment serial No. or ID, description of the test and the results of the testing.

3. Deficiencies identified by test or inspection must be corrected before further use or in a timely and safe manner.

4. For new equipment, the facility shall take steps to assure the equipment is suitable for the application.

 a. The facility will perform checks and inspections to verify that equipment is installed properly and per specifications and instructions.

 b. The facility will assure that spare parts and maintenance materials are suitable of the application.

5. MI is applicable to:

 a. Pressure vessels

 b. Storage tanks

 c. Piping (including components such as valves)

 d. Relief and vent systems

 e. Emergency shut down systems

 f. Controls (including monitoring devices, sensors, alarms, and interlocks)

6. This element of PSM/RMP is addressed in internal document MNT-SOP-010, Mechanical Integrity.



Operating Procedures:

1. CJ Bio America must provide operating procedures (SOPs) for each activity involved in covered processes addressing, at minimum:

 a. Initial start-up

 b. Normal operations

 c. Temporary operations

 d. Emergency shutdown

 e. Emergency operation

 f. Normal shutdown

 g. Startup following a turnaround or after emergency shutdown

 h. Operating limits

 i. Consequences of deviation

 j. Steps required to correct or avoid deviation

 k. Safety and health considerations including:

  i. Properties and hazards or chemicals in the process

  ii. Precautions to prevent exposure, including engineering controls, administrative controls, and PPE

  iii. Control measure

s if exposure occurs

  iv. Special or unique hazards

  v. Safety systems and their functions

2. Operational SOPs are readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the process,

3. SOPs for covered processes are annually certified as current by the owning department and reflect changes in chemical technology, equipment and the facility.

4. This element of PSM/RMP is addressed in Attachment #2 to the internal PSM & RMP Program SOP, Operating Procedures.



Process Hazard Analysis:

1. CJ Bio America will perform a PHA, at a minimum, every five years.

2. The PHA must be performed by a team of experts with expertise in engineering and process operations as well as at least one member of the team being knowledgeable in the specific PHA methodology being used.

3. Safe work practices are established for employees and contractors to control hazards during operations such as:

 a. Safe work permitting

 b. Lock out/tag out/try out

 c. Confined space entry

 d. Opening process equipment or piping

 e. Support personnel entrance into the facility

4. Methodologies eligible for use in PHA are:

 a. Whatif

 b. Checklist

 c. Hazard and operability study

 d. Failure mode and effects analysis

 e. Appropriate equivalent methodology

 f. Or any combination of items listed

5. The PHA shall address:

 a. Hazards of the process

 b. Identification of any previous incident which had a likely potential for catastrophic consequences

 c. Engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards

 d. Consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls

 e. Human factors

 f. A qualitative evaluation of a range of possible safety and health effects of failure of controls

6. CJ Bio America shall have a system to:

 a. Address the team's findings

 b. Document the resolution

 c. Document actions to be taken

 d. Develop a written schedule for completing actions

 e. Communicate the actions to affected employees

7. PHAs and updated must be retaine

d for the life of the covered process.

8. This element of PSM/RMP is addressed in internal document EHS-SOP-003, Process Hazard Analysis. The most recent PHA is included as Attachment #3 to the PSM & RMP SOP, Process Hazard Analysis Report.



Process Safety Information:

1. CJ Bio America shall compile written process safety information before conducting any PHA in order to enable CJ Bio America personnel to identify and understand the hazards 

   posed by those processes involving covered chemicals.

2. CJ Bio America shall document that the equipment complies with accepted engineering practices or that if equipment is designed with obsolete codes, standards, etc. that 

   equipment is designed, maintained, inspected, tested, and is operating safely.

3. CJ Bio America shall compile and retain written information on the equipment in the process, including:

 a. Materials of construction

 b. Piping and instrument diagrams (P&IDs)

 c. Electrical classification

 d. Relief system design and design basics

 e. Ventilation system design

 f. Design codes and standards employed

 g. Material and energy balances if built post

 h. Safety systems (interlocks, detection, suppression)

4. The following information, at minimum, shall be included:

 a. Toxicity information

 b. Permissible exposure levels

 c. Physical data

 d. Reactivity data

 e. Corrosiveness data

 f. Thermal and chemicaJ stability data

 g. Hazardous effects of inadvertent mixing of different materials that could foreseeably occur, SDSs may be used to comply with these requirements

5. PSI shall also include:

 a. A block flow diagram or simplified process flow diagram

 b. Process chemistry

 c. Maximum intended inventory

 d. Safe upper and lower limits for items such as temperature, pressure, flows, or compositions

 e. An evaluation of consequences of deviation

6. CJ Bio America has collected requisite information which was and will be used to perform the PHA.



Pre Start-Up Safety Review (PS

SR):

1. CJ Bio America must perform a PSSR, when applicable, on covered processes.

2. The PSSR must confirm prior to the addition of covered chemical(s) to a process:

 a. Construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications

 b. Safety, operation, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and adequate

 c. Training of each employee involved in operating a process has been completed

3. This element of PSM/RMP is addressed in Attachment #4 of the internal PSM & RMP SOP, Pre-startup Safety Review.



Training:

1. CJ Bio America must train personnel in the hazards of processes in which said personnel will be involved. Personnel receive initial training in the process and SOPs with emphases on safety, health hazards, and emergency operations prior to working in the process. Refresher training must be performed at least every three years.

2. This training must be appropriately documented, including:

 a. Identity of the employee

 b. Date of training

 c. The training is understood by the employee

 d. Means used to verify understanding

3. This element of PSM/RMP is addressed in the internal document HRT-SOP-002, General Training Guidelines, and internal document HRT-SOP-003, On-Boarding Process.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



1. Planning to upgrade the approach to account for post-incident head count (2019)

2. Complete a new PHA next year, which will account for the expansion project (as well as PSSR, Updated PSI, MI, etc.)

3. Installing digital signage to promote communication and employee participation (in progress)

4. Implement a LMS system to track training requirements (2019)

5. Considering a 3rd party contractor management system (2019)
